text: A game about a magical puppy who's the son of the sun goddess fighting demons to save the world. Only in Japan, folks.
author: SiegeSquirrel 42

text: For some reason, I played this before Okami. Still haven't completely beaten it, but I really liked it. Chibiterasu is an awesome protagonist, IMO. I actually think I might have experienced nostalgia from this track. Huh.
author: The13th Rose

text: The original Okami (PS2, Wii) is a Zelda-style adventure game based on Japanese mythology, with a spell-casting system where you draw brush strokes on the screen.  I haven't played Okami-Den, but that's the Nintendo DS Sequel.  Both games feature traditional Japanese style music like this track.

text: Xzaithyr Grymhart Okamiden is a DS adventure game in a similar vein to the Legend of Zelda series; it‚Äôs the sequel to the PS2 title Okami, and both have the principle of ‚ÄúWhat if all the ancient Japanese myths were true, and happened around the same time?‚Äù The land of Nippon (which is Japanese for Japan) is based on that. It‚Äôs worth a shot if you like Legend of Zelda.

text:
Much as I loved Okami... I really didn't like Okamiden.  At all.  The music was top notch, sure, but... the gameplay?  Lost all the charm from the original.

Sure, it was more difficult, but having to use the brush and wait for ten seconds for your fat ally to go anywhere, ALL THE TIME, got annoying in a hurry.
author: Honatuto

text: I just beat this game a couple days ago.  Worth every fucking penny.  I had doubts Capcom would be able to live up to Clover Studios' predecessor, but I was wrong (it helps that they at least brought back the same composer).  Definitely an epic way to end the DS era, as it's one of the best DS games I've ever played.

author: Dessa

text: Okami did not fail because of piraters.  It was pirated no more or less than any other PS2 games, and plenty of those were popular.  We're all aware that not everyone who pirates would have bought the game, yes?  Even if all the piraters did buy the game, it may still have been commercially unsuccessful.  I keep hearing people blame piracy for this games failure, but if you're gonna do it, back it up with some numbers.
author: Dessa

text: @LeahLuciB This may be shocking to you but this isn't my first time arguing via the Internet but thanks for explaining it to me...The real point of an argument is to compromise and learn a different POV of the topic rather then toss mud at each other. I don't expect pirates to stop stealing because of  my comments but I'm trying to speak to the gamers who sympathize with them. And yeah, the game industry is great for bland FPS's like CoD or Homefront. Oh, by the way, great music here huh? :)
author: SkepticalFox

text: @orwell9788 That I am being as bad as the sermonizers is entirely the point.  This is the internet.  People will say and do shit you don't agree with, and arguments, like this one, rarely have a chance of going anywhere.  Going on endless scolding rants about the nature of piracy doesn't do anything but be annoying.  I sleep with a free conscience. Does anyone really think youtube comments will change that?  Besides, the game industry is thriving.
author: Dessa

text: @orwell9788 And see how I responded to you like a respectful, fellow gamer instead of throwing in any condescending or snarky jabs? Maybe you can show me the same respect? <_<
author: SkepticalFox

text: @LeahLuciB I guess it's a golden rule on Youtube that you must respond to opposing viewpoints with a heaping dose of snark. Excuse me if I want Okami to get more backing for a sequel, isn't that beneficial to both of us? I'm glad you bought Okami, and yes publishers do take a wrongful amount of money, your absolutely right on that point, but treating gamers who pirate stuff are some noble rebels out to take down the "man" is just as bad as self-righteous sermons.
author: SkepticalFox

text: I bought Okami.  I buy video games, and rarely pirate.  I just hate self-righteous sermonizing.
author: Dessa

text: @LeahLuciB if they have nothing better to do, let them do it. i stated my opinion but i'm not gonna spend all day arguing about it. it won't help anyway...

text: @orwell9788 Mail the developers cash in envelopes if you care so much.  The publishers, who get the lions shares, are Scrooge McDucks.  Nice dissertation on world economy though.

text: @gott957 Lol, see what I'm saying?  These guys rage over this shit.  And there's nothing they can do about it but rage.  They just sit at home and wring their hands because somebody is wrong on the internet.

author: SkepticalFox

text: Huh, it's pretty sad seeing pro-pirating gamers on here, it's ironic that Okami isn't getting sequels on home consoles because it didn't sell that Ma
author: SkepticalFox

text:
Generally I'm against pirating games unless the developer really can't make a profit off it anymore, but in bluelaguna18's case, he doesn't live in the USA, or, presumably, another country where Okamiden was localized, so even if he bought it online he wouldn't be supporting his own country's economy. On top of that, he doesn't have a DS to begin with, so pirating the game is, in his case, a moot point because he's not part of the audience anyway.

Just thought I'd throw in my two cents.
author: Gantann

text: @subgerocallidus thank you for understanding me. and i know..... i know that support makes a difference in the gaming industry too. thanks alot again.

But if we want more Okami games, more people need to buy the game legit. It's a conundrum alright.

text:
@blulaguna18 It's about supporting the developer, which you are failing to do. A lot of work goes into making these games, and at the end of the day, it's a business. If the developer does not have the money to make another game or support it, then that's the end of it. We got lucky that Okamiden was even released after having so-so sales in the English speaking world. Your attitude is immensely selfish and part of a problem. 

You're stealing from Capcom and the chances of more Okami games.
